name: Ada Lovelace
blurb: Founder of what we know today as computer science, Ada designed the first algorithm intended for a computer, and envisioned capabilities of machines beyond simple number-crunching.

name: Alan Turing
blurb: Considered the father of computer science and artificial intelligence, Alan formalised the concepts of algorithm and computation with the Turing Machine. During WWII, Alan's work was instrumental in breaking German ciphers. He was also an openly gay man and was prosecuted for "homosexual acts" by the UK.

name: Andrew Chi-Chih Yao
blurb: Andrew's work as computational theorist, including "Yao's Principle," has significantly contributed to the theory of pseudo-random number generation and cryptography.

name: Anita Borg
blurb: Anita spent her career developing in areas of operating systems, memory systems, email communications, and more, while fiercely advocating for women in technology as the founder of the email network, Systers, and the (Anita Borg) Institute for Women and Technology, and as the co-founder of the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing conference.

name: Barbara Liskov
blurb: Barbara's work in programming language design and methodology, including the "Liskov substitution principle," contributed to the development of object-oriented programming.

name: Chieko Asakawa
blurb: A blind computer scientist at IBM, Chieko became an accomplished leader in accessibility research and development, including a key role in the development of web-to-speech system, IBM Home Page Reader, which is now produced in eleven languages and distributed worldwide.

name: The "Computers"
blurb: The primary programmers of the ENIAC, the six women collectively known as "computers" also knew their hardware, crawling inside the machinery to diagnose and debug problems.

name: Elizabeth J. Feinler
blurb: Pioneer and manager of various networks that became the basis for the Internet, Elizabeth also helped develop a program called PCSam, which became the basis of today's email systems.

name: Frances E. Allen
blurb: A pioneer in the field of optimising compilers, Frances introduced many of the abstractions, algorithms, and implementations used for automatic program optimisation technology.

name: Rear Admiral Grace Hopper
blurb: A pioneering programmer of the Harvard Mark I computer in 1944, "Amazing Grace" invented the compiler, which translates natural-language programming language to machine language.

name: Hedy Lamarr
blurb: An inventor and actress, Hedy co-invented the spread spectrum and frequency hopping communication technologies. They were used in WWII to control torpedoes and later used in Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.

name: Jennie S. Hwang
blurb: A pioneer in environmentally-friendly electronics manufacturing and electronics miniaturisation technology and a renowned entrepreneur, Jennie was also the first Asian-American woman to be elected into National Academy of Engineering.

name: John Forbes Nash, Jr.
blurb: John's contributions in mathematics, notably game theory, are influential in many fields including computer science and artificial intelligence. He was diagnosed and lived with paranoid schizophrenia, and his story became basis for the biography and film, "A Beautiful Mind."

name: Katherine Johnson
blurb: Renowned for her accuracy in celestial navigation (space flight trajectories), Katherine started at NASA as a "computer" in the all African-American West Area Computers section. She soon transitioned to work as an aerospace technologist, notably, making calculations for the Apollo space programs.

name: Klara Dan von Neumann
blurb:
A pioneer programmer and key inventor on the ENIAC*, Klara's work is often downplayed in comparison to her husband's. She also taught weather scientists how to program.
* The ENIAC was the first electronic general-purpose computer, announced in 1946.

name: Lynn Conway
blurb: Lynn's contributions include pioneering work in chip design, and architecture design that laid the groundwork for modern high performance microprocessors. In 1968, IBM fired Lynn Conway when she revealed to the company that she was transgender, and she subsequently was denied access to her children after transitioning. In 2000, she went public with her story as a trans woman, and began her work in activism.

name: Manuel Blum
blurb: Manuel's machine-independent theory of complexity forms the foundation of computational complexity theory, the study of the "difficulty" of computational problems.

name: Margaret Hamilton
blurb: As lead Apollo flight software designer at NASA, Margaret and her team built the software allowing Apollo 11 to successfully navigate to and land on the Moon. She co-developed concepts of asynchronous software, priority scheduling, and more, which became foundational to robust software designs.

name: Mark Dean
blurb: At IBM, Mark led a team for the design of a one-gigahertz computer processor chip. He holds three of IBM's original nine PC patents and is the first black person to become an IBM Fellow.

name: Peter Landin
blurb: Inventor of the first software emulator, Peter freed computer programs from manufacturers and laid the foundations for programming language design based on mathematical logic. Peter was politically radical, bisexual, and highly active in the Gay Liberation Front.

name: Radia Perlman
blurb: Radia made large contributions to network engineering, and is best known for her invention of the spanning-tree protocol, a technology fundamental to network bridging (connecting multiple networks).

name: Raj Reddy
blurb: One of the early researchers of artificial intelligence, Raj pioneered the study of spoken language systems, such as voice-controlled robots, speech recognition, and dictation.

name: Shafi Goldwasser
blurb: Researcher of cryptography, computational complexity theory, and computational number theory, Shafi co-invented the zero-knowledge protocol, a key cryptographic tool.

name: Sophie Wilson
blurb: Known for designing the Acorn Micro-Computer, Sophie also designed the instruction set of the ARM processor that now drives billions of mobile devices. She is also an out transgender woman.

name: West Area Computers
blurb: "West Area Computers" was a unit of all black female aeronautical research mathematicians at NASA. The unit was originally supervised by white supervisors and segregated under Jim Crow. Dorothy Vaughan, a black female mathematician, eventually took over as supervisor.

name: Yukako Uchinaga
blurb: At IBM, Yukako led the team that developed software to work with Asian languages such as Chinese, Japanese, and Korean, that require "double byte character sets." She has also been deeply involved in advocacy for women at IBM Japan and Asia Pacific, as well as the Japanese government.

name: Zero
blurb: The first known use of the number zero was in Egypt, where the hieroglyph also meant "beautiful." Without the concept of zero, there would be no computer science as we know it.
